data.text:
I‚Äôve been thinking about this for a few days, and while I don‚Äôt have it fully worked out, I think there may be a way to mitigate some of the social-media dysfunction we‚Äôre all downstream from.

I‚Äôm a longtime Ray Dalio fan. At Bridgewater, they implemented a true meritocracy: people were ranked based on their demonstrated expertise in a given domain, and the weight of their opinions on that topic was adjusted accordingly.

Most organizations operate under an authoritarian model. The drawbacks are obvious. Others swing toward democracy, which is an improvement ‚Äî but often inefficient.

Which raises an interesting question:
 What if social platforms incorporated some form of expertise weighting ‚Äî so that thoughtful, informed voices were amplified over the loudest or angriest ones?

Is that unrealistic? Or is it exactly what‚Äôs missing?

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
I‚Äôm a constant consumer of LinkedIn content and of the broader ‚Äúhow to improve your life and career‚Äù ecosystem. If there‚Äôs one theme that‚Äôs impossible to miss, it‚Äôs this: your network‚Äîused intentionally and generously‚Äîis one of the biggest levers you have.

As Derek Sivers puts it, if knowledge alone were enough, we‚Äôd all be millionaires with six-pack abs. Execution is the differentiator.

One of the simplest ways to execute better is to build a system for tracking your outreach and holding yourself accountable. That can be something like Clay (a fantastic company and team) or just a well-organized spreadsheet. Make a list of the people you want to reconnect with, track the touchpoints, and score the strength of the relationship. And‚Äîsomething I repeat often‚Äîif it‚Äôs not in your calendar, the odds that it happens are close to zero. Block 1‚Äì2 small windows each week.

If you want next-level structure and more strategies, take a look at Beyond Connections. It‚Äôs been one of the most valuable investments I‚Äôve made in my career. https://lnkd.in/geuDH5Uf

data.text:
Quick LinkedIn tip: the algorithm can start to penalize you if you have too many unanswered connection requests.

Here‚Äôs how to clean them up:
Network ‚Üí Invitations ‚Üí Manage ‚Üí Sent

 Withdraw anything older than 2‚Äì3 weeks.

It‚Äôs a small habit, but it can save you frustration later ‚Äî especially when you‚Äôre trying to connect with someone and the ‚ÄúConnect‚Äù button suddenly disappears.

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
Most of us know ‚Äî intellectually ‚Äî that people tend to be more respectful and productive when communicating live rather than over email or text. Yet we don‚Äôt always act on that knowledge.

In practice, many of us avoid conflict (or are simply worn down by it), so we default to email or Slack for conversations that would be far more effective if handled live. We optimize for short-term emotional comfort, even when the medium is clearly working against us.

Here‚Äôs a rule of thumb I‚Äôve learned over time: if emotions are even slightly elevated, or if you‚Äôve had more than five or six back-and-forths without resolution, it‚Äôs time to talk ‚Äî face to face or voice to voice.

It may be uncomfortable for a few minutes. But more often than not, you‚Äôll leave with clarity, forward momentum, and a stronger relationship than you had going in.

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
In Sales, the marathon of outreach and follow-up can turn into a grind fast. My approach has always been to stay close to what actually works: test, analyze, refine. Is it increasing the number of touchpoints? Improving relevance and personalization? Offering more value? Trying multiple channels? Usually, it‚Äôs a mix of all of the above.

But lately, as I‚Äôve been exploring how to operate at my highest level, I‚Äôve started adding one more ingredient to the mix: inspiration.

I didn‚Äôt expect this to be a missing piece. I‚Äôve spent years in personal development programs, sales training, and GTM strategy work ‚Äî and somehow I still overlooked how much energy the right idea or phrase can generate. But I‚Äôve always been a logophile; I love language, and I‚Äôve long kept lists of quotes and words that resonate with me. Turns out, the motivation I needed was sitting in plain sight.

The line that hit me today was: ‚ÄúThe best life has one foot in joy and one foot in suffering.‚Äù

A simple reminder that the hard parts aren‚Äôt interruptions to the work; they are the work.

What‚Äôs giving you energy or focus today?

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
Like public speaking and paying taxes, there‚Äôs another universal human dread we don‚Äôt talk about enough: having hard conversations.

I was definitely conflict-avoidant earlier in my career. It took me longer than I wish to realize that this skill ‚Äî the ability to address something difficult with clarity and respect ‚Äî is a genuine superpower. And once you develop it, it changes everything. Not just professionally, but in your personal relationships as well.

I was reminded of this today while sharing some concerns with someone on my team. I was struck by how thoughtfully they listened ‚Äî asking questions, seeking to understand, and taking real ownership. I did my best to speak only from my own experience, acknowledge the limits of my perception, and leave room for context I might not have.

When both people handle these moments well, the trust and respect that follows is profound. These conversations deepen relationships, not damage them.

And here‚Äôs to hoping this is one uniquely human skill that AI never quite learns.

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
I really feel for the job seekers navigating today‚Äôs market ‚Äî it‚Äôs tough out there. And the truth is, what worked before isn‚Äôt necessarily working now.

Here‚Äôs the thing: job hunting is a skill. Like any skill, it can be learned ‚Äî and those who lean in and build it intentionally are the ones who will see real dividends.

At the heart of any effective job search is networking ‚Äî though I prefer to reframe it as relationship building. (That reframe comes from Connected Success, which has been incredibly valuable to me.)

Another reframe: approach this process ‚Äî and really, every interaction ‚Äî with generosity. When your outreach is centered on the other person and focused on reconnecting, helping, or simply showing genuine interest, it becomes not just more effective, but more enjoyable.

 And when you enjoy it, you‚Äôll do it more ‚Äî and that‚Äôs where the magic happens.
The people you already know and have worked with are your greatest resource right now. Reach out. Offer to help. Co-elevate each other.

None of us can do this alone ‚Äî so don‚Äôt try.

 And if I know you and can be of help, drop me a DM.

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
‚ÄúHow to Sell (and Not Feel Icky About It)‚Äù

Having spent my career in Go-To-Market roles ‚Äî and being a bit of a wannabe psychologist ‚Äî I find it fascinating how uncomfortable so many people are with selling.

Here‚Äôs the truth: even if you don‚Äôt carry a quota, you‚Äôre still selling every day.
Convincing your teenager to do their homework before playing video games? That‚Äôs sales.

I‚Äôm a big believer in ethical selling ‚Äî influencing in service of what‚Äôs best for others.

In that parenting example, your intent is good: you want what‚Äôs best for your kiddo. They know that ‚Äî and that‚Äôs what makes your ‚Äúpitch‚Äù land.

The same principle applies in business. My goal in every sales engagement is to be the most assertive, polite, and respectful person my prospect has ever met. 

Over time, they come to see that their success is my goal ‚Äî because ultimately, my success is tied to theirs.

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

resharedPost.text:
My time-tested script for meeting anyone new:

Give. Give. Give.

When I meet someone for the first time, I‚Äôm not thinking, "What can I get from this person?"

Instead, I‚Äôm asking myself, "How can I help them right now?"

Relationships grow through generosity.

The people who give first and often build networks rooted in trust.

So next time you walk into a new room, try leading with that script:

Give. Give. Give.

And watch what happens next.

author.headline: #1 NYT Bestselling Author | Keynote Speaker | Executive and Team Coach | Architecting the Future of Human-AI Collaboration

data.text:
I could not agree with Keith's advice more. I've been in the GoToMarket space my entire career and I've seen this strategy work consistently. 

When approaching a prospective new customer, you have to earn the right to sell to them. You do that by being generous. Be generous with the industry and product knowledge you have. You can also do it with your relationships (pro tip....take Keith's Beyond Connections course and learn how to run community dinners that deepen relationships). 

All good relationships are based on trust and respect. The more generous you are, the more of each you will earn. 

Thanks for lighting the way Keith Ferrazzi

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
I know firsthand how brutal the job market is right now. Most of us have been there at one point or another.

One piece of advice I often share ‚Äî especially with people not in sales ‚Äî is this: reframe your job search as selling yourself.

Having worked with many job seekers (both formally and informally), one of the biggest challenges I see is how uncomfortable people are with the idea of ‚Äúselling‚Äù themselves. It‚Äôs understandable. But that mental shift ‚Äî from job seeker to trusted advisor presenting value ‚Äî can be a real unlock.

Yes, there are bad actors out there who give sales a bad name. But there‚Äôs also a way to approach sales that‚Äôs ethical, authentic, and doesn‚Äôt feel icky.

In my own work, I always anchor on one thing: the value my product or solution delivers to customers. The same principle applies in a job search. If you focus on the value you bring to a prospective employer, it will:

¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Make the process feel more natural and honest
¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Help you reframe how you communicate, with a lens on the outcomes you create
¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Make it easier for employers to quickly answer the question, ‚ÄúWhy should we hire this person?‚Äù

Job hunting is a skill ‚Äî and an important one. If you‚Äôre looking for practical tips on how to sharpen that skill, one of my favorite resources is Austin Belcak.

You‚Äôve got this. üí™

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
I‚Äôm always looking for the patterns that create big unlocks across multiple areas of life.

After decades working in the Go-To-Market world, one lesson has stood out above all others: listening is the better part of communication.

We all have a natural tendency to want to express our thoughts and opinions. But when you catch yourself waiting for someone to finish speaking so you can respond ‚Äî instead of truly listening ‚Äî that‚Äôs the perfect moment to pause, lean into self-awareness, and raise your listening game.

I was reminded of this again during a Braver Angels meeting last night. If you‚Äôre not familiar with this incredible organization, their mission is to foster thoughtful, respectful cross-political conversations. Sitting in a room where people ask honest questions, listen deeply, and have no agenda to ‚Äúconvert‚Äù anyone gives me hope ‚Äî and reminds me how extraordinary our country can be when curiosity and respect lead the way.

Listening is, after all, the only way to take in new information and evolve your understanding of reality. Whether you‚Äôre helping a customer solve a business challenge or trying to bridge divides in civic life, it all starts with listening.

It gives a whole new meaning to the phrase ‚Äúlisten up.‚Äù

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
We all know times are tough right now. The real question is: what should we do about it?

For me, the answer depends on what I‚Äôm trying to accomplish ‚Äî and I‚Äôve found it‚Äôs best to prioritize activities that unlock multiple goals at once.

The biggest one? Networking (though I prefer to call it relationship building).

Looking for a new role? ‚Üí Start with your network. They care about you, they know you.
Want to start a side business? ‚Üí Who in your network has already done this?
Trying to learn a new skill (AI, anyone?) ‚Üí Who in your network is already strong in that area?
Need to synthesize your thinking on a complex topic? ‚Üí Who in your network could deepen the conversation? (Pro move: schedule a dinner with a few people who will make it fascinating.)

So how do you go about building and cultivating more meaningful relationships?
For me, the answer was Beyond Connections. It‚Äôs one of the best things I‚Äôve done in years ‚Äî the methodology, the community, and the results have been invaluable. The next cohort starts soon, and I can‚Äôt recommend it highly enough. https://lnkd.in/geuDH5Uf

However you approach it, here‚Äôs to investing in your relationships. They will pay dividends in more ways than you can imagine.

data.text:
I‚Äôve been meeting with some amazing startup founders lately who have one thing in common: they need revenue.

I know, I know‚Ä¶ that sounds obvious. (One of my mottos has always been: there are few business problems that can‚Äôt be solved with more sales.)

But here‚Äôs what struck me: so many of these founders dislike selling so much that it becomes a real barrier to reaching out.

One simple reframe seemed to unlock things for them:
 What if your goal was simply to be the most gracious and polite, yet assertive, person your prospects have ever met?

The look on their faces when I said that was priceless ‚Äî it was like they suddenly gave themselves permission to start the conversation.

Some lessons from kindergarten still apply in business: Be a good human.

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
Most people are uncomfortable with sales.
 I get it ‚Äî I‚Äôm not a pushy person either.

 But here‚Äôs the truth:
 More of your success than you realize will be defined by how well you sell ‚Äî no matter what your role is.

‚úÖ Want a job? You have to sell yourself.
 ‚úÖ Want a promotion? Same thing.
 ‚úÖ Want to work for yourself? Multiply your sales efforts by 1,000.

So what‚Äôs the unlock? Do such great work that selling becomes a service.
 When you reach out, pitch, or advocate ‚Äî you‚Äôre not bothering anyone; you‚Äôre helping them.

I call this ethical selling.

It‚Äôs not about tactics; it‚Äôs about integrity.

 It‚Äôs about showing up with value and making the next move easier for the people you serve.

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
In my efforts to stay current ‚Äî especially with the explosion of AI strategies ‚Äî I attend a lot of webinars.

Here‚Äôs my frustration: so many of them never share how long the session will be.

This drives me bonkers. Like most of you, I‚Äôm juggling this on top of my day job. I need to plan my time so I can keep the bulk of my day focused on actually getting things done.

I get it ‚Äî there‚Äôs probably an algorithm or data set somewhere suggesting that leaving out the duration improves attendance or engagement.

But here‚Äôs the other side of that equation: the human one.

If you want to land on my calendar, please give me both a start and end time.
 Just sayin‚Äô.

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
Public Service Announcement: Time Zones Matter üï∞Ô∏è

Friends, please ‚Äî include time zones when scheduling calls.

I set up a lot of meetings with people across different time zones (and often different countries). You‚Äôd think by now this would be standard practice, but surprisingly, even some executive assistants skip this step.

If I‚Äôm asking for your time, I‚Äôll make the effort to figure out where you‚Äôre located and send invites in your time zone. It‚Äôs a small courtesy that makes a big difference.

But if you‚Äôre asking for my time, help me help you ‚Äî don‚Äôt make me solve the mystery of where you are like it‚Äôs an episode of Carmen Sandiego.

Pro tip: My go-to tool for juggling multiple time zones is World Time Buddy.

Let‚Äôs make scheduling a little less confusing, one time zone at a time. üåç

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
How do you build your product roadmap? I often see product teams rely heavily on internal expertise to shape their products. Having spent years understanding why customers buy what they buy, I can tell you that the most valuable insights aren‚Äôt generally found in brainstorming sessions or strategy documents ‚Äî they live with the people who actually use what you build.

Your customers experience your product in real-time and in real‚Äëlife contexts. Their feedback highlights hidden pain points, unmet needs, and unexpected delights. By consistently listening, you can spot patterns, validate hypotheses, and challenge assumptions before they become costly mistakes.

That‚Äôs not to say you should ignore feedback from your customer‚Äëfacing teams ‚Äî there will usually be a high degree of overlap ‚Äî but in my experience, direct customer feedback carries far more weight. Firsthand user experiences reveal nuances that get filtered out internally. Make sure your roadmap starts with the voice of the customer.

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
Sales basics still matter. Even for the seasoned pros.

One of the things I love most is learning new things. But in the process, I sometimes forget to consistently practice the tried-and-true habits that I know work. Habits I used to be religious about, but that I let slip when things get busy.

Lately, the one that's caught me is the simple confirmation email.

After almost any call, it‚Äôs good practice to send a quick summary and next steps. I still do this pretty consistently with customer calls‚Äîbut I‚Äôve gotten a little sloppy with internal ones.

And that‚Äôs where I‚Äôve been burned. Someone agrees to something, but without a written recap, it slips through the cracks. Totally understandable. But now I‚Äôm restarting the process, and it‚Äôs on me‚Äînot them‚Äîto stay sharp on the basics.

The good news? With AI tools, generating those summaries is easier than ever. No excuses.
#SalesBasics #RevenueLeadership #Partnerships #GTM

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
I‚Äôm a big believer in partnerships as a force multiplier. Decades of Go-To-Market experience have taught me this again and again.

But here‚Äôs the thing: the people who consistently get things done also tend to hold high standards.

The same should apply to your partners.

In my experience, it‚Äôs less an 80/20 rule and more like 90/10 when it comes to partnerships. A small percentage of partners will deliver the majority of the value.

But that 10%? They‚Äôll make it rain.

So yes, expect to do some slogging to find your 10%. But once you do‚Äîbring an umbrella and something sturdy to hold onto. üåßÔ∏èüí•

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
I recently had the privilege of sharing revenue-generation and partnership strategies with an incredible group of entrepreneurs in the TiE Oregon program‚Äîone of the most dynamic cohorts I‚Äôve seen.

The energy in the room was electric‚Äîso many creative ideas, bold visions, and inspiring products. And, of course, the fear. It‚Äôs a constant companion in entrepreneurship, especially in the early days when success can feel distant and uncertain.

But here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve learned: fear fades when revenue starts flowing. That‚Äôs why I always guide founders to prioritize sales early. And in my experience, the fastest path to sales is through partnerships.

Find the people who are already selling to your ideal customer. Help them win‚Äîdeeply and generously. Help your customer win too. That‚Äôs the heartbeat of a great partnership.

Test, measure, refine. Then do it again.

Here‚Äôs to the boldness, creativity, and resilience of this amazing group of builders. Onward!

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
Saying entrepreneurship is hard is like saying water is wet. Of course it is.
But the hardest part?

Generating revenue. Full stop.

Granted, I‚Äôve spent my career in GTM and revenue, so maybe I‚Äôm the person with a hammer, seeing nails everywhere. Still, whether you're running a business or a household, everything gets easier when you can hire the right people, buy the right tools, and attract the best opportunities.

So what‚Äôs the fastest way to grow revenue?
Partnerships.

Find the people who already work with your target customer.
Find 20.
Partner with 1 or 2.

Because here‚Äôs the truth:
Other humans and companies are the wormholes to whatever future you‚Äôre trying to create.

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
Gratitude, in the face of disillusionment.

Life and work tend to run in cycles‚Äîhard, then inspiring, then hard again. Lately, I‚Äôve been in a stretch where I‚Äôve been digging into the backstories of some of our most prominent business and political leaders. And honestly, it‚Äôs been disheartening. The level of recklessness, ego, and short-term thinking is staggering.

But here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve learned over and over again: the antidote to disillusionment is to focus on where things are going right. Specifically, paying attention to the good ones‚Äîthe people who lead with integrity, who play the long game, who show up with generosity, clarity, and care.
To the colleagues, mentors, customers, and friends I‚Äôve had the privilege of working with‚Äîpast and present‚Äîwho bring curiosity, rigor, warmth, and wisdom into the room: thank you. You are a reminder that meaningful work and good humans still go hand in hand.

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
Sales is built on trust. Ethical sales, especially. And trust is usually earned over time‚Äîbut it can be lost in an instant.

For years, Alaska Airlines was one of my most trusted brands. But in the past year, I‚Äôve noticed a shift. Less focus on the customer. Fewer moments that feel like someone really cares. And last week, when I left my phone in an airport bathroom at SFO, that shift became a clear break in trust.

The initial mistake was mine. But what followed revealed just how much had changed. Poor processes. No one willing‚Äîor empowered‚Äîto help. A refusal to even walk seven minutes to a gate where ‚ÄúFind My‚Äù clearly showed my phone was sitting. I was even told it had been turned in to Lost & Found... but it never was. Ironically, the police had a process to recover it‚Äîif only Alaska had followed theirs.

What companies often miss is this: when something goes wrong is your best shot to earn a customer‚Äôs loyalty. I would‚Äôve walked away from this experience more loyal than ever. Instead, I walked away for good.

Whether you‚Äôre a startup or an enterprise: it‚Äôs easier (and far smarter) to grow the trust of your existing customers than to chase new ones.

Play the long game.
#CustomerExperience #SalesLeadership #TrustInBusiness

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
Give first. Give generously.
 Especially in the age of AI, I believe this is how we:
 1Ô∏è‚É£ Build truly meaningful professional relationships
 2Ô∏è‚É£ Stand out in a world that's rapidly changing
Will you get burned? Absolutely.
 For me, that‚Äôs happened more on the personal side than professional. But like anything you want to get better at, approaching setbacks with radical responsibility leads to better answers ‚Äî and ones you can actually control.
I‚Äôve created some guardrails for myself: ways to spot issues early, work through them when possible, or move on when it‚Äôs time.
In my world, I often collaborate with System Integrators and services partners. My advice? Lean in. Be generous with what you‚Äôre seeing in the market. Share what‚Äôs working for your customers. Even get a little personal with your counterparts.
The result? Deeper trust, stronger outcomes, and better results ‚Äî for everyone involved. Especially your customers

data.text:
I am so excited to share this. @Keith Ferrazzi is launching his very first in-depth Networking Training.

We‚Äôve all heard the age-old cliches about networking. 

You are the product of your network. No one successful ever got there alone. People do business with people they like.

You may think that to build a world class network you‚Äôve got to be super charismatic, or an extrovert, right?

Wrong.

Sure, charisma helps. 

But what‚Äôs more important is having a system in place that is effective and that you follow consistently so you're always top of mind to the right people.

And when you do engage with those people, you've got to be able to go deep and build rapport - quickly and consistently. Because the goal is really to build relationships, not just a long list of barely-acquaintances. 

These are not things you're born with. They can absolutely be taught.

A study published in Harvard Business Review last year tracked almost 2,000 partners at professional services firms to understand what the rainmakers were doing differently.

What they found was that the ‚ÄúActivators‚Äù as they called them had a system of regular, weekly activities in their calendar. And the system was focused on grooming their network of relationships.

Those Activators generated 30% more revenue than their peers in the study, and 50% more revenue than the worst performing persona (the Experts‚Ä¶who banked on publishing articles to help them close deals with clients).

I‚Äôve known @Keith Ferrazzi since he published his NYTimes #1 bestseller Never Eat Alone twenty years ago.

The book sold 1mm+ copies, has been translated into 15+ languages, and is one of the classics on networking.

I‚Äôve heard Keith called the most networked man in America.

And to celebrate this anniversary, Keith and his team have taken the most powerful practices from this book and created a live, online training program called Beyond Connections.

They are enrolling now, and spots are limited for the first cohort beginning this June and running eight weeks.

So if you want to be more strategic about your network and learn how to build deep, lasting connections‚Ä¶ you can apply to the program here: https://lnkd.in/geuDH5Uf

The worst kind of clickbait 

‚ÄòLet‚Äôs get people hired - post your jobs in the comments below. If you‚Äôre looking for work put your information in the comments so recruiters can find you‚Äô

These types of posts are proliferating, and they‚Äôre completely disingenuous. Please don‚Äôt engage with them. 

Recruiters are not trawling through the comments of ‚Äòinfluencers‚Äô looking for candidates. Not in any universe is this happening. All it‚Äôs doing is creating engagement for the ‚Äòinfluencer‚Äô, which is frankly despicable.

Engineering social clout by misleading and manipulating people looking for work is a very special kind of wrong. Please stop it. 

Ironically, I need to ask you to reshare this so that more people will see it ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
We all know how important communication is to our personal and professional lives.
¬†
One of the things I‚Äôve been paying a lot more attention to over the last decade, both at work and at home, is the balance and intensity of communication.
¬†
I‚Äôve noticed that when things get stressful, most of us are comforted by certainty (or the illusion of it). I think that without realizing it, that often means looking to the loudest or most confident voice in the room.
¬†
Maybe we need a new name for this all-too-human fallacy. Because the loudest voice in the room is often not the rightest voice in the room. I think this is part of the gender dynamic that becomes problematic as we work to evolve our society. In stressful situations, men tend to display more anger and/or control. Women lean more toward questioning the steps that led to the undesired situation and consensus building. Anger and control inspire confidence. Questioning and looking to others for their opinions doesn‚Äôt usually.
¬†
Please note that I have little patience for the ‚Äúmen are scum and/or women are crazy‚Äù narrative. The only productive path forward involves a nuanced blend of raw truth, grace toward other humans and extreme ownership of our own role and actions.
¬†
I recall a great podcast interview with Indra Nooryi (and Tim Ferriss) where she gave an example of this. She was an SVP at the time and was frustrated at not being heard by the other male SVPs. In an exec meeting, she turned to the male SVP next to her and asked him to propose an idea (she said this in a way so that the entire room could hear the exchange). He was confused and asked why she didn‚Äôt propose it. She explained that it would get dismissed if she voiced it but that it had a much greater chance of being heard if he said it. To their credit, the other SVPs worked with her to address and resolve the issue.
¬†
We‚Äôve all seen men who are aggressive and dominant. But we‚Äôve all also seen women who are too passive and too quick to stand down. Neither is ideal in every situation.
¬†
Obviously, leaders need to be mindful of and intentional about heading off this dynamic. But we ladies do as well. Pick your time and place, but whenever possible, we need to speak up and help others around us see what‚Äôs happening.
¬†
To solve hard problems, which is what we need to do in the current climate, we‚Äôre going to need to do things we haven‚Äôt done before. We need more ideas and voices at the table and we need to listen (really listen) to voices that have not are not being heard.

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
Having been in the corporate world my entire career, one unsettling trend I‚Äôve observed, which has only picked up steam, is the focus on short-term goals over long-term ones. My hope is that we can all use this current market as a reminder of the importance of playing the long game.
¬†
Job seekers can make contacts and have interesting conversations, even with companies that may not be hiring right now. Many of them will be hiring in Q1 of next year.
¬†
Employers can continue to work on their talent brand, development programs and build out some great pipelines that were hard to impossible to create 6 months ago.
¬†
And maybe we can all start to look farther out than the next quarter (this from a quota-carrying sales rep)‚Ä¶.

data.text:
For those those people interviewing right now, I wanted to share something that is simple but not necessarily easy (and one I‚Äôve seen Senior Director's mess up). Be ready with a strong answer to the question "Tell me about yourself"
¬†
Here‚Äôs an easy way to get ready - Your answer should take about 2-3 minutes to deliver and ideally covers what you‚Äôre doing now, previous experience (school counts) that is relevant to this job, and what kind of role you are looking for and why this one is interesting to you and (for bonus points), why you‚Äôre a good fit.

To that end, I have a swipe file with different versions intro notes that I'd be happy to share with anyone looking. Hit me up if you're interested.

data.text:
Simple strategy for building out your pipeline of diverse candidates. Put the candidates you‚Äôve engaged with, interviewed, people who‚Äôve attended your diversity events, registration lists for any summits or events you‚Äôve participated in, and build out a monthly outreach and keep them warm. Include stories about or short videos of some of the awesome diverse talent you already have today.
¬†
I know, it sounds so ridiculously simple, but I can report that most of the Fortune 500 companies I‚Äôm talking with aren‚Äôt doing it.
¬†
¬†Happy to share examples or more detail on what goes in those outreach cadences. #diversityhiring

author.headline: Senior Go-To-Market Strategist | Revenue Acceleration & Business Development | Enterprise AE l Speaker l Driving Revenue Growth & Strategic Alliances

data.text:
Something I‚Äôve struggled with my entire career is the pressure to meet quarterly targets (hiring, revenue, whatever) which forces leaders to optimize for the short run and not the long term. We have one Fortune 100 client who made 15 hires from one diversity hiring event over 9 months. Here‚Äôs the kicker. They say the ROI from the event was too low because they only made 2 of those hires in the first 45 days.
¬†
Everyone I talk with is trying to hire more diverse talent. But here‚Äôs the thing‚Ä¶..it takes longer. I‚Äôm a big fan of experimenting. So, if you want to hire more diverse talent, try adjusting your quarterly targets to annual targets and see what happens. #diversityhiring

I had the immense pleasure of sitting in on a talk with a few ServiceNow folks who are part of their Latino ERG (Unidos). I was blown away and so inspired by their commitment to help others, hard work in the face of so many obstacles and raw human goodness.
¬†
I work for such an amazing company and our customers are some of the most beautiful humans I‚Äôve ever had the pleasure of working with. And yet I rarely let myself take the time to just sit in on these sessions and grow from and bathe in the wisdom, insights and beautiful energy. Thank you for the reminder to fix this Isabella Frediani Jennifer Boicic Marcus Torres
